description: Hemodialysis permits 3 sessions/week while hemodiafiltration permits only 2 sessions/week

medical_analysis.clinical_rationale: Both HD and HDF are renal replacement therapies for ESRD requiring equivalent weekly clearance targets
medical_analysis.evidence_base: KDOQI guidelines recommend 3x/week minimum for both modalities
medical_analysis.contraindication_check: No clinical reason for HDF to have lower frequency
medical_analysis.clinical_equivalence: Both modalities should have consistent session access

impact_assessment.health_equity_impact: Creates treatment disparities based on coverage not clinical need

evidence_documentation.policy_text_hd: Maximum of 3 sessions per week for haemodialysis
evidence_documentation.policy_text_hdf: Maximum of 2 sessions per week for hemodiafiltration

clinical_consequences.immediate_risk: Patients may receive inadequate dialysis if forced into HDF coverage
clinical_consequences.provider_burden: Clinicians forced to choose coverage over optimal treatment

recommendations.immediate_action: Standardize both modalities to 3 sessions/week minimum
recommendations.policy_revision: Align session limits with clinical protocols not procedure type
recommendations.implementation: Allow medical officer discretion for frequency based on patient needs

description: Open heart surgery is only available at Level 6 facilities, potentially limiting access for patients in regions without such facilities.

medical_analysis.clinical_rationale: Open heart surgery requires specialized equipment and personnel typically found at higher-level facilities.
medical_analysis.evidence_base: Standard practice for complex surgeries to be conducted at tertiary care centers.
medical_analysis.facility_requirements: Level 6 facilities are equipped for high-complexity procedures.

impact_assessment.health_equity_impact: Geographic disparities in access to life-saving procedures

evidence_documentation.policy_text: Open Heart Surgery available at Level 6 facilities

clinical_consequences.immediate_risk: Delayed access to critical surgical interventions for patients in remote areas
clinical_consequences.long_term_impact: Potential increase in mortality and morbidity due to access barriers
clinical_consequences.provider_burden: Referral and transfer logistics complicate timely care delivery

recommendations.immediate_action: Enhance referral networks and transport systems to facilitate access to Level 6 facilities
recommendations.policy_revision: Consider partnerships with regional centers to expand surgical capabilities
recommendations.implementation: Develop telemedicine support for pre- and post-operative care in lower-level facilities
